div.head: To the most Vertuous LADY Mrs. JOANNA THORNHILL, VVife to the Honourable Col: RICH: THORNHILL, of Ollantigh in KENT.
div.p: AS my many Obligations to your Name, in both your Relations of Husband and Brother, have long since claim'd from me a Publique Acknowledgement, so those to your Person have created in me a Confidence, not only to obtain Pardon for this Presumption, but a Protection of this Innocent Stranger, who durst not venture abroad without it. Such is his Innocency, that in this habit he might, without Gaule to the Spectators, have enter'd the Theater (had not the Guilty Ones of this Age, broken that Mirrour lest they should there behold their own horrible Shapes represented) but now he is faine to seeke Sanctuary, which cannot be found, but at the Altar of an Immaculate Vertue, which (Madam) all that are so happy as to know you, confesse to be raised in your Name, under whose shadow, as under Laurell, poore Lysis will not onely be secured from the Thunder of the Times, but I shall be absolved from my Errors, and confirm'd, with all Devotion, to continue in all Gratitude,

closer.signed: Your most humble Servant, T. R.

list.item: ANGELICA a Nymph, Sister to Montenor.
MONTENOR a Sheepherd in love with Lucida.
ANSELM a Sheepherd in love with Angelica.
LUCIDA a Sheepherdesse, sister to Hircan.
CHARITA a Sheepherdesse, Cousin to Angelica:
SYNOPE CLORISE Damosels, Neighbours to Angelica.

div.head: Actus primus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Lysis in the Equipage of a Sheepherd driving his Flock before him.
div.l: FEed my dear Sheep, faithful Companions feed
Through all those verdant plaines from danger freed;
Thanks to my Shepherdess, we now behold
An Age, as glorious as that Age of Gold.
But on the Gilliflowers, and Roses feed,
That spring in ev'ry place, where Shee doth tread;
Taste without feare, no food so sweet will prove,
'Gainst Wolves; your Centinel's the God of Love;
He loves what She affects, and kindely looks
Upon her faithfull Sheepherd and his Flocks.
Flocks, which long since being marked for his owne,
Feel no diseases, that in Sheep are known.
Charita, thou faire Sheepherdesse, whom we
Adore, the flower and choice of all in Brie:
How powerfull thine eyes! how bright! how faire!
By which, thus to keep Sheep, thy Lovers are
Constrain'd! compar'd to their bright sparkling rayes,
The Sun it selfe a gloomy light displayesâª
Whose weaker Beames are but Reflexions vaine,
When those of thy bright eyes begin to raigne.
Therefore, poore Sun, thy fault's beyond compare,
That still presum'st t' illuminate the aire;
Quit, quit that care to th' Object I adore,
Thy shame unto the world expose no more:
Lie close within the Seas, nor day, nor night
Thy Chrystall Palace quit, nor Amphitrite.
But since thou wilt goe onâ'tis best for me
To feast my selfe with this frugalitie.
Feed, feed my pretty Lambs, while I like you
Thus sitting on the grasse, the same will doe.
div.stage: Ent. Clarimond. [He sits down, and taking fruits out of his pouch, looking back, he spies Clarimond, who surprized to see a man clad like an ancient Roman Shepherd, stood still to view him.]

sp.speaker: Lysis.
sp.l: Pan guard thee Sheepherd, whither art thou going?
Art thou dispos'd to taste our Sheepherds fare?
I have some other fruits within my pouch,
And those wee'l share, and feast the best we can:
And if we thirst, the River is not far.
Pray take your place.â

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I thank ye, Ile not eate,
I have no stomach,âbut good Sir, resolve me,
What great, important businesse brings you hither?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I like thy freedome, and I love thee for't:
To be inquisitive doth argue Wit,
And Curiosities when th' are discreet.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: O no more complement!âwhat art thou prethee?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: What am I? Sure thou canst not but discerne:
Sheepherd (I thank God Pan) I am a Sheepherdâ
But what remote Country dost thou inhabit
That art thus ignorant of th' affaires of Brie?
For though thy garments differ much from mine,
I guesse thou art a Shepherd too.

sp.speaker: Cl
sp.l: 'Tis true,
I am indeed so, and perhaps to morrow
I shall more plainly shew you what I am,
In the meane time, may I know your condition?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I'me too good Natur'd to deny thee that.â
Sit downe.

sp.speaker: Cl
sp.l: Who e're saw such extravagance?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: For thy sake, I'le put up my fruits againe,
To me the Hour's indifferent, and you know
A good Discourse is better than a Feast,
Besides the brizes that refresh these plaines,
Make the place very proper for our Story.
Know then that Love, (that Son of Chaos) who
So often doth disturbe his mothers rest,
And were it not for whom we Sheepherds might
Scorne the felicity of greatest Kings,
This blinde cleare-sighted God, this peevish Boy,
Endeavour'd to enslave me from my youth:
But, knowing how he us'd to treat his Captives,
I still avoided that mischievous God;
And I had fool'd him yet a thousand times,
If to subdue this heart so long assail'd;
Finding that all his Forces were too weake,
He had not call'd Charita to his aide,â
Charita!âoh how that faire name doth ravish!

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Shee's faire then?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Fair? faire with Hyperbole,
Heap up a thousand fairest things together,
Thinke of the Lillies beauties, and of Roses,
And borrow for her eyes the Sun's bright rayes;
Plant on each cheek the best Vermilian Dye,
Then with a faithful Pensil vively paintâ(Scratches
Wel Sheepherd (to be brief) conclude her fair. his head)

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Wonderfull piece!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: It was at Paris, where
Before I was a Sheepherd I was taken.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: And as shee then took you, so you took her!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Could she hold out against so great deserts?
I shall not tell thee, what sweet Trances then
I felt, and with what Extasies transported,
Nor how to make her yeilding to my sighs,
I dy'd a thousand times, as oft reviv'd,
I'le onely tell thee, that my greatest blisse
Proceeded from a project which Love taught her.
Perswading her to come, and live in Brie,
Here to revive the antient Sheepherds Life,
Some five or sixe dayes since she hither came,
And made my blisse that of the Gods exceed,
For truly I know none, so perfect, as
To live a Sheepherd, and to sway the Crook.
Ther's neither Tree, nor Rock, in all these parts
Wherein we have not Character'd our Loves;
And were it not for one thing that I feareâ

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Dost thou feare ought?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Yes left some ugly Satyre,
Lest some Goat-footed God, enamour'd of her,
Finde her alone, and maugre all her criesâ

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Fie, no, your Love's too apprehensive; here's
No Satyre, but o're whom I doe command,
Rest satisfied.

sp.speaker: Lysis
sp.l: Doe you then give them Lawes?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: They know me well, and tremble under me.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Great Deity of these our sacred Grovesâª
Accept the homage of thy prostrate Sheepherd;
For 'tis to Pan I speak, who in my love
T'assist me, is thus purposely disguis'd,
Thy more than humane looks makes that too cleare.
Pardon me that I knew thee not before;
Henceforth upon thy Sacred Altars, I
Will daily offer-store of Milk and Wine,
And every Month will choose the fattest Lamb
Of all my Flocks, to be thy Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What meane you Sheepherd?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Suffer me this day;â

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: You injure Pan to worship Me for him,
Observe Mee well; for such a Festivall,
I doe both want his Hornes, and cloven-feet.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Your mortall habit hides Divinityâ

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Ah Foole art there?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Couz Adrian! Is't you?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Yes it is, I'me tormented with thy follies;
Art thou come hither then to play thy pranks?
Would thou wer't safe i' th' Hospitall of Fooles!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Peace; give me leave my reasons to alledg,
(For that should be the refuge of us all)
This gracious Sheepherd here shall be our Judge:
Deciv'd with his perfections I e'en now
Took him for Pan disguised like a mortall,
Nayâlook you to't, he hath the countenance,
If not of Pan, of Mercury, or Cupid.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Oh Heaven! what Folly, what Extravagance!â

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You blame the Sheepherds, but alas, too blindly;
Is any life more full of sweets than this?
Is not their Name, as antient as the World?
And when Deucalion would mankinde restore
Out of the first Stone he a Sheepherd made.
And Kings of old (whom I am proud to follow)
Made their Sons Sheepherds, as the way to live.
The Gods, on Earth have often ta'ne that habit,
And great Apollo kept Admetus Sheep,
And even those wandring Starrs, we see above
Are Beasts, that feed within those shining plainesâª
And who are fit to keep them but the Gods?
Then, for our Sheep, what is of greater worth?
We feed upon them, sheare them, and receive
The yearly tribute of their wealthy fleeces.
And as they say (the more to be ador'd).
Iove once transform'd himselfe into a Ram,
And Greece ne're knew a nobler enterprize
Then when the Argonauts fetch't home the fleece,
'Tis the first Sacrifice was made to Pan.
This is to let you know, (Couz Adrian)
That though the World revile it, yet to lead
Our Flocks to feed 's a noble exercise.
And to what serves your tedious noyse of Cities?
Of Merchants, Officers, or Advocates?
Read Iulietta, and then tell me, if
Arcadia ever knew such names as these?
They all were Sheepherds, and liv'd free from care,
And I would have them here to be so govern'd.
Beleeve me (Cousin) leave your City trades,
Let us together dresse our Pastures, bring
Your Wife, your Children,âhere you'l live at ease:
Shee shall a Sheepherdesse, they Sheepherds be,
And we will all in perfect pleasures live,
And to the Bag-pipe, under Elmes wee'le dance.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Ah (Sir) you see, to what a strange excesse
This poore Phrenetick Spirit is transported,
How much extravaganceâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: My deare Charita!
If thou dost kill me, give me life againe!

div.stage: [He retires to a corner of the Stage, where he lies downe.]

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: While he talkes to himselfe, be pleas'd to tell me
The hidden cause of that which troubles him,
I finde his frantick fits, of a strange nature.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: It's the issue of a vaine, and cursed reading:
His Father was a Merchant and Citizen
Of Paris, and being rich, look't on him onely,
And thinking to provide for him an Office,
T'adorne his innocent, and harmlesse minde,
Caus'd him to Study, where all that he learn't
Was to o'rethrow that little wit he had.
He read Romances onely, and believ'd them,
Admir'd all the Sheepherds fain'd adventures,
And his weake braine by those vaine fables, did
So soon descend in th' Aire of Love, and Beauty:
That in a year or two he thus besotted
Would wilfully assume this present habit:
'Twas labour'd with much reason to convince him,
But he still talkt of Sheep, and of his Crook,
Yet studied more, but thought lesse of his office,
And though he still persisted in his frenzy,
Yet was it worse, when his good Father dy'd:
The Romance of Astraea was then publish't,
Where reading Hylas, and Sylvander's jarres,
His braine being very soft in such a case,
He needs would be their judge, and heare them plead,
And so resolv'd to goe into the Forrests,
And, had not I still caus'd him to be follow'd,
He doubtlesse more had credited his booke,
Than our advice. His Frenzy still continuing,
He oft would lock himselfe into his Chamber,
Where without let, pursuing his wilde fancies,
I've heard him act the Sheepherds part alone.
In fine, the Mode of these Romances ceasing,
His minde a long time seemed lesse distracted,
And certainly that Heat began to coole,
Had he not haunted Comedies last Winter:
When, earnest oft to see their Amaryllis,
H' againe reviv'd his thoughts of Flocks and Crooks.
He drew me too to see that cursed Play;
And cry'd at ev'ry line, O wonderfull!
Scarce could he keep himselfe within his skin,
All seem'd so ravishing, so rarely new:
Never was Man there, more intent than He,
'Twas Acted, and he there an hundred times,
So that imbark'd againe by their leud babling,
And finding time to make his bundle ready,
And all trust up, he early in a morning
Came hither, thus to act his foolish part,
But I shall put such Fetters on him, that
He shall no longer thus dishonour us.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: His humour's troublesome, but yet take heed
Lest your confining him should breake his quietâª
A Prison's terrible to soundest mindes,
And the diseas'd it oft exasperates.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: 'Tis true; but what amendment can I hope?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: If you'l advise with me, let him alone,
What do'st concerne you here? Y' are farre from Paris,
Let him accomplish what he has design'd,
Let him pursue this Sally of his thoughts,
Perhaps a week, or so, may cure his folly,
And he not finding in a Sheepherd's life,
The fancied pleasures that entic'd him to it,
It may more easie prove to make him see
The errour, which his books did first create.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Well, for a day or too I'le leave him then,
Although I came by chance into this place,
And have gone very farre to finde him out.
M' affaires engage me to a quick returne,
Th' are pressing, and of great importance to me.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Farewell; I'le have a care he shall not wander.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter to them Anselme, in the habit of a Sheepherd, Lysis lying still talking to himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: H' as left us here inestimable treasure:
Was ever fool of a more pleasant humour?
But what illusion's this surprizeth me?
What i'st? is all the world turn'd foole like him?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What! Clarimond it seems does hardly know me;

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! in what a shape dost thou appear?
I'st Anselme?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Yes I'me Anselme still for you.
But my Romantick Name is Polidore.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: D'ee act a part in some new Comedy?
Or hath this Foole involv'd you in his follies?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You know him then?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Arriv'd here yester-night
I've almost learnt already his full story,
Himselfe did spend much time t' informe me in it.
But there is one Charita much in's thoughs;
Who's that rare Object?

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: I'm pleas'd with this surprize:
You name Charita, and ask who she is.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What, is't that faire One now with Angelica?
Her Cousin?

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: The same: 'tis she that wounds him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Being entangled in such easie chaines,
Although his thoughts did erre, his eye did not:
But since this beauty is the same Charita,
Whose merits I have oft proclaim'd at Paris,
I'd gladly share the incomparable sport
This day to be a Sheepherd, and his Rival,
Induc'd to this disguise by your example.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Faith do not wonder that you see me thus;
Tis Angelica's power over me.
Her service is so sweet a Law to me,
That knowing Pastorals did alwaies please her,
I'm made a Sheepherd, Charita a Sheepherdess,
She likewise acts her part, but one more gentle,
For her, among us, we have made a Nymph.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: This needs must be as pleasant as tis rare;
But I must let her know what I intend,
She being a Nymph, we all must seem to court her.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Ah!â

div.stage: (crying out awaking from a dead sleep.)

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: What aile ye Sheepherd?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: 'Twas a stretch of Love.â
I thought my soule was quitting its abode,
Musing upon that fairest faire Charita.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Indeed th' are pleasant thoughts, and worthy of you,
But we must leave you in so sweet a rapture;
Farewel, the Heavens have care of what concerns you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Courteous Sheepherds, Pan have you in his keepingâª

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter (to him) Charita in the habit of a Sheepherdesse.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Faire Birds which daily in the Aire do move,
And singing praise the Object of my Love,
What equall to her merits do you see?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What doe's this Fool alone? what are his thoughts?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: But I to mutes in vaine my speed apply,
I'de better speak to th' Eccho of these groves,
Who oft to reason with us Sheepherds love's.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I'le be his Eccho, 'twill be a rare Scene.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Nymph I, of Love unheard-of torments, beare,
I've often spoke it, did'st thou never heare?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Hereâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Good She replies:âbut since my griefs, by chance,
Are known, how shall I cure their great abundance?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Danceâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Well sing or Whistle, and I'le daunce with you:
Charita sayes she loves me,âis it true?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Trueâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: But I can nought obtaine, though I ne're cease
T'entreat her ease the paines that me oppresse.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Presseâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Well said, I'le now beleeve thee, 't shall be done,
And to demand her aide I'le straitway run.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Runâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Farewell. So may thy minion ev'ry day,
Narcissus visit thee where e're thou stay.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Stayâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Stop me? did'st thou not say my torments by
Her sight should all be cured happily?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I-lyâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Leave jesting, and my cruell paines abate,
What must I hope for then? her love or hate?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Her hateâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: What shall I doe, alas, if weeping I
Cannot her minde appease? sad Tragedy!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Dyâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: But what death shall I choose, if, so abhor'd
I begge her aide, and she will none accord?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: A-cordâ

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: A Cord? ah you surprize me now, you know,
I have no Cord, but that on Cupids bow:
Nymph, is not that the Cord for which you call?
Answer.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No 'tis a Cord to hang thy selfe withall.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Foolish, and sottish Nymph, you prate too much;
Whence comes this humour in you? are you drunk?
Or knowing th'art lesse faire than my Charita,
Envy or shame hath made thee talke so fast.
I see herâmy faire Starre!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Before a Goddess men ought thus to kneel,
And ever with all reverence receive
The influence of her Divine aspects.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: No, Sheepherd no, I hate all such respects,
These adorations may seem good at Paris,
But here men ought to live in a full freedom.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: 'Tis true, 'twas ever granted unto Sheepherds;
Oh high design, and rare, inspir'd by love!
To quit foul Paris for this pleasant place!
What a delicious life shall we enjoy?
The Gods themselves, the Gods do envy us.
Sometimes assembled, we shall laugh and dance,
Sometimes we shall retire againe alone,
Sitting sometimes in shades, sometimes on Fearne,
Where thou shalt call Me Sheepherd, and I Thee
My Sheepherdess, and placing Love between us,
Play at a thousand pretty little games,
And sometimes gatherâCharitaâmy soulâ
Helpâhelp thy Sheepherd that's now swooningâahâ
Cruel dost thou recoile?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Have I not reason?
If you should swoon your fall may crush me too,
To me your body does not seem so light,
But that it well may hurt your Sheepherdess.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Go, th'art inhumane, and I now perceive
Th'ast no remorse for all th'ill th'ast done me;
Thy heart's of Brass, Steele, Marble, and of Stone.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What have I done that merits this reproach?
Have I, that I should now be thus abus'd,
Provok'd you by neglect, or have I scratch'd you?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Yes, but you have no sense (malignant Beauty)
The nailes of your aspect do daily claw me.
And, the sharp rayes of your so glittering looks
Have given me here a wound will nere be heal'd.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis true; their force is somewhat terrible,
Yet do not think the wound's incurable;
Ile cure youâbut farewell untill anon.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Hard Anaxarete! art gone so soon?
See how thine Iphis grieves at thy departure.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I hast to finde the Sheepherdesse Lucida,
Th' expect her at the Nymph's.â

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Thou mak'st me tremble!
Why dost thou aggravate so great a grief?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: D'ee feare to see her?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Ah!âI've cause to feare,
No Sheepherd hath more reason to complaine,
I fly what me pursues, and love what flies me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You still are angry when she followes youâ
But oft disdaine, conceales a reall flame,
And y' are more tractable perhaps in private.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: With her in private? no believe me, faire One,
The heart of Lysis is so chain'd to thee,
That thou shalt have it chast, pure, and unmixt,
Entire: and sooner than Ile turn to change,
Or other beauty shall have power t' ensnare me.
Rivers shall run revolted from the Seas;
Those liquid Courts shall want their Nayaedes
The Hamadriades, and the Faunes forsake
The Woods, and all the World new Orders take,
And Wolves against the Doggs our Flocks defend.â

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: This solemne Oath hath given me faith at once,
Farewell kinde Sheepherd.â

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Sheepherds Farewell.
My heart's committed to you, have a care on't;â
Go my dear Lambs, seek Pasture farther off,
For Sol's too scorching rayes by shining here,
Hath burnt the grass, and left these places bare.

div.trailer: The end of the first Act.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: A Little complaisance, and Sheepherds habit
Seeme to engage you in designes of Love,
But pray no more of this disguise with me,
Impose not this constraint upon your selfe
And believe, without speaking more of Love,
Your worth's sufficient to gaine esteeme.

sp.speaker: Monten.
sp.l: Hath the mild violence of a love so pure
So little power to perswade you then?
And since your faire eyes set me all a fire
T' avow it is complacencie enough.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Thus credulous Spirits are too easy taken,
And though men are all Ice they'l sweare they burne,
But this discourse of fire proves little heat;
The more you say, the lesse I do believe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your humour's contrary to Lovers hopes;
How can you know their flames if they keep silence?
And if they speake they are believ'd deceitfull.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Love hath an ideome to explaine it selfe
I' th' midst of silence, it speaks, and perswades,
And its least motion's fill'd with Eloquence.
One sigh oft in a moment utters much,
He must speake low whom th'heart not understands.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If th' heart so well Love's language apprehend,
Would yee have clearer evidence of mine?
My heart hath sigh't an hundred times near you,
My languishing as often hath declar'd it,
And daring not t' express the wounds you gave me,
I oft strove to interpret with mine eyes;
But their sad looks could not express their story:
And, though some foolish hope may dare presume,
The cunning'st sighs have but dumb Eloquence
If th' heart consent not to its own surprize,
Nor can their correspondence well consist,
If Love perswade them not to lend an eare.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Then that's the cause I have not understood
What you pretend, your sighs have signified:
But two or three piping, and dying groanes,
Have often prov'd false pleadings of true love,
And since you see I understand it not,
You happily do seek advantage by it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Doubt not an Heart so subject to your Lawes;
Be witnesse all you Trees within these Groves
How oft alas, there, seeking solitude,
I've entertain'd them with my sighs and groanes,
How oft I've boasted of that glorious power,
Your eyes in secret practice on my soule.
How oft rehearst the wounds their beames have given me.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: When they tell me so, Ile believe my share.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Cruel, is this then all that I can nowâ

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Hircan's my Brother, I depend on him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Judge better of my flame, and know though 'tis
Extreame, 'twill ow your heart to none but you:
And that 'twill use in the pursuit none butâ

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Peace Montenor, the company is coming.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter to them Angelica, Anselme, Charita.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sheepherds believ't my joy's beyond compare,
To see you so well act the Sheepherds part;
Blush not Lucida, Phillis and Lycidas,
Were often wont to single out each other,
And great Diana nere refus'd to talk
With Paris, or Syliander from the rest.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: You make a just construction, yet I doubt
Who ere accuses me, may do the same,
If Polidor's discourse had pleas'd you lesse,
You would perhaps have sooner found us out.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sister, she hits you home with her reply.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Sh'as reason, I confesse, for what she sayes:
Our coming sooner might have more disturb'd ye,
Had he had nothing private to say to me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Thus may all four (methinks) live full content,
Mean while I have my share among ye too,
While sweets on sweets are heaped up for you,
I'm fain to entertain my selfe with thoughts.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Yet we are taught to understand thy worth,
Whose beauty has, this day, begot such Rivals.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Build not so much upon anothers ruine,
My time perhaps may come as well as yours.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: I were an Infidel if I should doubt it,
Since Clarimond becomes a Sheepherd for thee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Knowing, that for my sake, our foole thus sighs,
He ought at least to swear't for laughters sake.
Yet faith, let him dissemble as he please,
Wee'l see at last how well he will escape.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Thou never speak'st to thine own disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I hate the foolish use of a false vertue;
Who from himselfe expects nought, nought receives.
Methinks our Rival-Sheepherds tarry long.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: 'Tis here that Lysis leads his Flock to feed,
And we shall see him here ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: He has a Language may be call'd his own.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: His discourse heretofore was lesse unsmooth,
But since he Virgil read, in Bumbast verse,
His Tongue is laden with Fantastique Words,
And thinks that all the Gods speak just the same,
And concludes that the best of Dialectsâª

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: He has an empty skull.â

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: So dull a head!
That he could not discern me by my voice,
When I instead of Echo answered him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Can he endure your jesting, being mad?
Butâhist,âI heare him sing.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Pray hide your selves,
And be spectators of our raillery;
Ile give him now his belly-full of Love.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Nay hold, pray first let's heare his courtly Aire.

div.stage: (They all hide themselves behinde the Trees, except Lucida, who accosts him after he hath sung.)

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: When Love to two united hearts,
The sweets of prudent flames imparts,
How pleasant 'tis the Crook to beare!
How sweet of Sheep to have the care!
Thus sitting by a Chrystall brook,
A Sheepherd sung, whom love had strook,
To love a Sheepherdesse how sweet!
How pleasant 'tis when Loves do meet.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Faire object of my flames, and my misfortune,
May this day prove more blest to Thee than Me!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: In vain thy flame, troublesome Sheepherdess,
Doth claime a compliment, not meant to thee.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: When wilt thou cease, thus to make War upon me?
And lay aside these scornes that break my heart?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: When Elmes shall the embrace of Ivy flie,
And rav'nous Wolves with Lambs live peacefully.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Though thy severity doth still encrease,
Ile be the same that ever I profest.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Ixion heretofore embrac'd a Cloud,
And so Lucida may embrace the Wind.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: The raging Seas at last will leave their fury,
So may thy hatred have a time to cease.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: As Rocks unshaken stand against those billows,
So is my heart unmoved by thy love.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: For Pan's sake, Sheepherd, and the Hamadriads,
Refuse me not a civil entertainment.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: If they the maladies of Love can cure,
Th' hadst best go offer up thy vowes to them.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: 'Mong Scythians fierce, at thy Nativity,
Thy heart was fill'd with Ice, nothing can thaw it.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Derive me (if thou wilt) from Caucasus,
So thou no more disturb me with thy Love.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: May thy best Sheep be left a prey to Wolves,
If thus to rigour thou expose my Soule!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I'l suffer them to come within my folds,
When thou shalt have possession of my heart.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Thou Tyger, nurst up by a Tygress fierce,
Thy proud disdaine will open me my grave.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: So farre am I from a designe to kill thee,
I never had a thought to touch thy skin.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Thou dost distract my soule, and thy sharp talons,
Soon as I see thee, teare it into pieces.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I know not how to patch up a torn soule,
And, prithee, what should I do with the pieces?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: You may cement them but with one sweet word,
And from an Hell of woes raise me to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: If such a thing as that can cure thy folly,
Of Honey, or of Sugar take thy choice.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Grant either of them to my constancy,
Of Hope the Sugar, of thy Faith the Honey.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: If thy fond constancy do Hony need,
Farewellâyou must seek other Bees than Me.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Stay thou bright Torch of my too am'rous life,
Suffer my flames at least to live in hope.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Thy life's in danger to be wondrous dark,
If I'm the Torch that must enlighten it.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: If for thy high deserts, that name's too low,
Se thou Apollo, and vouchsafe to cure me.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Thanks to thee (Sylvia) I must be gone;
If I'm the Sun I must be ever running.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter (to them) Angel. Anselm. Montenor, Charita.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Whither so fast, good Sheepherd?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Prudent Nymph,
I'm in Retreat before mine Enemy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Will not Lucida speak to us to day?

div.stage: (Lucida going aside, as if unwilling to be surpris'd with Lysis.)

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: No, let her stay a while behind those bushes,
And give her time to recollect her Soule
From th' trouble of her late rejected flame.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: She then persists to persecute you stil.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Any but Lysis would be tempted by her,
But though her love of me doth still afflict her,
Charita's still Charita, she Lucida.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And since my Sheepherd all contemnes for me,
He has most really my heart, and faith,
Our soules are both possest with equall flames.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Truce to these sweets a whileâyou ravish me!
Oh.â

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Sigh yee?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Sheepherdess my careâ
'Tis a precaution that I thus doe sigh,
Lest too much ardour should at once surprize me,
And I soone finde my heart reduc'd to ashes,
By the too active flames of my desires.
Did not the Air of these my sighs refresh it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Why talk ye with the Honour of our plains?

sp.speaker: Ch
sp.l: We talk of Meddows, pastures, and of Flocks,
We must dissembleâ

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: And we likewise talk
Of that faire shining eye, that caus'd my griefe,
Yes, of thine eye divine, thou charming beauty!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Such language, Sheepherd, does affront your Mistris,
The brightnesse of her eyes, you see's not common,
They both can charme, and yet you praise but one.
What Rapsodie of love doth make you talk so?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Why I assume the language of the Poets.
This style to them was ever held peculiar,
I purposely, like them, spoke but of one,
But yet with no designe t' offend my fairest;
For either of those Suns afford me light,
And when I sweare her faire ey's skill'd to charme,
I speake no more o'th' left than of the right

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What say you now Nymph?

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: 'Tis a prudent answer.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Silence!âI heare farre off a Bagpipe's sound.â
Oh how melodious!â

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis by a young Sheepherd,
Who not long since arriv'd from a strange Country.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: 'Tis true, his habit's different from ours.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: To live amongst us he assum'd another,
He's here.

div.head: SCENE V.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You then desire, gentle Sheepherd,
Henceforth to dwell with us, in these faire Plaines?
Your change of Habit makes me so presume.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I'm come for cure of my consuming flames.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Sheepherd, I then perceive you are in love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ahâ'tis too true, I languish night and day;
But say (I pray) before I tell my story,
Doe I not talk with the Nymph Angelica?

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Yes, if on her depends your Remedy,
She's ready here to give you all assistance.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Great Drudge! fam'd for thy mirac'lous art,
I here attend thy Oracles effects!
Love make thee now propitious to my fires!â

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: What charming object forc'd from you that sigh?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas! that I dare not presume to tell you

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Sheepherd, you may, nor feare to hurt,
All here partake already of your griefe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I adore her in Idea though unknown.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Not know her?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Heare the story of my life,
My name is Philiris, in Arcadia born.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: That Country alwaies fruitfull was in Sheepherds;
But to heare't better, let us all sit round,
It is the Pastorall Order.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Take your place.â
Here's green Turf.â

div.stage: (They all sit down, Lysis lying at Charita's feet.)

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Oh my dear Sunâfor Heaven's sake,
Mod'rate thy Rayes, or thou wilt quite consume me.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Come now (Sir) all are silent, you may speak.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Know them great Nymph, and you faire sheepherdesse,
You gentle Sheepherdsâsuch are my misfortunesâ
In that blest Climate where I first took birth,
Pan is less fear'd than is the God of Love:
For that no Hearts, no Sheepherds are so great,
Whom that fierce Tyran doth not make his Slave:
(And would to the just Heavens that I could dobut
Whether his yoak be easie to be born)
But yet admire by what strange prodigie
My freedome's subject to his cruell lawes;
Sitting one day beneath a shady Elme,
Free from all care, although I kept my Flock,
Surpriz'd with sleep, congested beames of light,
Depriv'd my senses of their wonted vigour,
And then discover'd to my blinded eyes,
A precious treasure of unheard-of charms:
A Sheepherdess, in whom the Graces seem'd
To chuse their places, as if there enthron'd
A lovely Arrogance, a noble State
Seem'd sweetness there to joyn with Majesty
Nere did the Gods in a more noble frame,
See forth the Image of their Deitie:
OhâNymphâI saw her, judge then how I lov'd her,
How with those sudden flames my heart was fir'd;
And what strength the surprizall of my sense
Could leave me, to resist her charms assaults!
But sad Catastrophe! when day was ended,
I found my Error so, but not my Love.
My soule possest of so great rarities,
When I awak'd still kept their strong Idea,
But so confus'dly, that I never could
Retrive the Object, where those Beauties shin'd,
Yet still I lov'd that imperfect Idea.
Here did my freedom finde its overthrow,
And from that instant I am so in love,
That I have no esteem for other objects.
Thus forc'd to love, and without hope of comfort,
I am constrain'd to burn, and yet be silent.
But though this sad constraint augments my pain,
I must detect the secrets of my heart:
A famous Drudge, that when he is private,
Seemes daily to interpret Destiny:
Was th' Oracle Divine, that by these words,
First gave my wav'ring spirit some repose.
Rejoyce sad Sheepherd, the Decree
Of Fate, shall soon accomplisht be
Within the Realm of Lillies, neare
The Banks of Marne, a Nymph thou there
Shalt finde, Angelica by name,
Discover unto her thy flame,
Open unto her thy Heart,
The strange Originall impart
Of this thy fire, then to thine eyes
The light of a new Day shall rise,
That soon the sacred Beauty shall discover,
Whose Image in thy Dream made thee a Lover.
sp.stage: (He riseth, and as it were suddenly surprized with a new light, continues his addresse to Charita.)
sp.l: But Gods! What see I now? What rayes of light,
That in an instant thus unseele mine eyes?
Oh Sheepherdess, 'tis you that thus have charm'd me,
Your wonderfull Idea 'twas thus inflam'd me:
You are the lovely object of my sighs,
You whoâ

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Soft, Sheepherd, you are pleas'd to say so,
Goe to Arcadia there to act your Trances:
Charita is my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And mine too.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: This heat is very quick.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yet 'tis extream.â

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Pitty thy selfe, for Heaven's sake honest Sheepherd,
If I'm thy Rivall, what hope's left for thee?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Some promise to themselves more than they get.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: My flame as the more ancient shall pervaile.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That which I feel is full as great as thine:
Tis more than three yeares since my heart was wounded.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Gods how this wonder does amaze my thoughts!
What sayes Lucida?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: The Sheepherd does deserve
For all these services Charita's love,
And to possesse her heart.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: What you plead for him?
AhâNymph, I die, at least am very near itâ

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To lose no time in frivolous disputes,
Let's see what deeds will answer all these words,
My passion prompts me to a glorious project;
Charita is the object of our Loves,
And both of us sigh equally for her;
And since the cause of our dispute's so faire,
Let Combat here decide it in her sight,
And shew which of us doth deserve her best,
She shall be judge.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Agreed, it shall be so.
Renounce her for a few dry bangs o'th' Crook?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You will be Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: I do not doubt it,
If thy faire eye stand second to mine arm:
Pan give the victory to my boundlesse love,
And I will hang his Crook between thy Horns!
Sheepherd prepare thy selfâ
sp.stage: (As he puts himselfe into a posture to fight with his Crooke; Clar. drawes out a Sword hid within his Crook.)
sp.l: But what means this.
A sword? Art mad thus to defend thy self?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: T'enjoy Charita you must take my life:
Think of death onely.

sp.speaker: Ly,
sp.l: I have no such thought.
I'm a Sheepherd of Honour, and no Murtherer:
Besides, though I were nere so stout in fight,
What can my Sheepherd arm against a sword?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Courage brave Sheepherd, I will make 'em equal,
sp.stage: (Taking likewise a Sword out of his Crook presents it Lys.)
sp.l: Too happy to oblige the best of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Oh Villain Sheepherds with their iron tooles!

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Here take this sword.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Desperate Lysis,
Refuse a Combate for Charita's sake!
Why all the world must know this cowardize!

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: And why? I've heart enough to serve my turn:
Butâ

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: What need ye press me farther?
Ile not infringe our customes for a world.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: What custome is't you mean?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Where can you shew me,
That ever any Sheepherds fought with Swords?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Yes, once Filander for Diana fought.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: True, to secure her from prophane assaults;
But yet he fought with Slings, and to his cost.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: W'ave said too muh t'excite this Sheepherds valour;
His want of love appeares to faire Charita,
For his refusall gives her up, and quits her.
Brave stranger, come the victory is yours.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How much that sweet Decree makes me your Debterâª

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: And thou ingrateful Sheepherd that dost fear
To shed one drop of thy ignoble blood,
And durst not hazard for thy Love that little
Was wanting, to orecome and to possesse her:
Go, it's apparent now thou wert a Traitour;
Dare not to come hereafter in our sight.
Sheepherds let's go.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Ah cruell-hearted Nymph!
Than Myrmidon, or Dollope more fell.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Farewell sad Sheepherd.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Ah what dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The sentence being past we must subscribe.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Dost thou forsake me then?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I'm in despaire;
Yet may the Gods permit us meet again:
In th'mean time die not, but live still assur'd,
Thou nere shalt see thy Rivall in thy place.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Flatter my woes at least by sighing for me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I grieve for both of usâbut no more sighs;â
My heart is so lockt up I cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Oh of all faire Ones the most unrelenting!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Perhaps you suffer least in this our parting:
FarewellâPan comfort and dwell ever with thee.

div.head: SCENE VI.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Let's yeild to Fate and satisfie her rage,
And end our daies within some salvage den:
Farewell ye dearest places, and my flocks,
Which feeding I have left on yonder hill,
Y' ennamel'd meddowes, which too apt to please,
Have furnisht me with flowrs t' adorn my Love:
And pleasant streames farewell, despairing Lysis
I'th' horrour of these Woods will ever dwell.
Good Gods! how thick, how dark it is! I think
No Sheepherd ere its silence did disturb:
Hence all prophaneâtake heed you come not neare;
I feare to touch them as I crosse these bushesâ
Ohâth'are the rusling leavesâI think I see
A man that walks there with a staffe in's hand,
And murm'ring to himselfe, does seem to read.

div.stage: (He perceives Hircan walking (after the Country-fashion) with a Cane in his hand, reading.)

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Doubtless it is a Druyde skil'd in Magickâ
I must accost him.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Great and learned Druyde,
If that divinity, that here presides,
Did ever comfort an unhappy Sheepherd,
Vouchsafe thine aide to offer him my vowes.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: This certainly's that Fool with's Pastoral life,
Whose pleasant madnesse is so much discours'd.
May'st thou be so content as thy offerd vowes
Ought to be heard, by those great Gods I serve,
Haesus and Taramis are to Sheepherds kinde.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I 'mbrace the happy auspicies to see you,
And for so rich a blessing thanke my fate:
Daigne then to cast your eyes on a poor Lover,
All's possible to you, move but your staffe,
And nature straight is subject to your Lawes.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: He takes me for a conjurer. Ile comply
With his mistakeâSheepherd all shall be well;
Thy griefs shall be redrest what ere they be,
All things give way to this mysterious charm,
Ask, and be sure I can do any thing.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: No Sheepherd's so unfortunate as I,
By th' fatall sentence of a cruell power,
I'm banisht from the house of Angelica;
So lose Charita, and must never dare
Henceforth, so much as to approach those walls.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: And is't this banishment that so afflicts thee?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Was ever Lover more severely punisht!
I, in despaire of aid, enter'd these Woods,
Against me to provoke the Beares and Tygers.
But if by Magick skill, you shall vouchsafe
To let me see my Love at Angelica's,
By rendring me invisible or transform'd.â

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: This is the easiest secret of my Art:
All w'ave to do is to disguise your sex,
To cheat the Nymph, and see your Sheepherdess
Take womans habit, and go thither weeping,
Require them to relieve your great misfortunes,
Fain that the fatall influence of your starres.â

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: This Metamorphosis is very Past'rall:
So once Austraea did embrace Alcais,
Not knowing that 'twas Celadon disguis'd.
But to appeare a Maid indeed, how shall I
Be rid of this excrescence of my beard?
How shall I this correct?

sp.speaker: Hircan
sp.l: That's a slight Scruple;
Ohâlet thy beard alone, feare nothing, I
Can by my Art give thee the countenance
Of a yong Sheepherdesse, extremely faire.
Thy maine so modest, and thy port so taking!
Charita scarce can be a minute from thee.
Then judge thy happiness, shee's sure thine own.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: What priviledge shall I have thus disguis'd?
I am impatient till it be accomplisht.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Let's to my Palace to begin the work.

div.trailer: The end of the second Act.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: I See at length that Lysis company
Hath power to draw you from your solitude,
Allowing us excuse for our disguises,
While you partake of our divertisement.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: I must confesse his folly is so pleasant,
It much exceeds all that is spoken of him:
For my part I much wondred when I saw
My Sister was a Sheepherdesse for him,
And certain pastimes which she then pursu'd,
Scarce could I yeild to such a low design.
But things unknown with injury are censur'd:
And Lysiâª humour is so pleasing to me,
That were not by's error pre-engag'd,
I could resolve to take the Crook up too;
But yet I hope to make you all confesse,
There is some pleasure in a Druyd's part.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: You onely study then to come off well;
In Comedies variety is pleasant,
And I am confident this will be so.
Some Sheepherds, I a Nymph, you Conjurer.â

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: But yet 'tis! have made the best adventure.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Yes doubtless, it will be an excellent Scene,
When to appeare a Maid hee I thank't enough,
To imitate the Gestures, and the Habit.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Yet I did nothing, but with Ceremony,
I pray'd to Tharamis, invoakt his Genius,
Then casting round my eyes to ev'ry place,
Thrice to the East I fixt my countenance,
And thus with a grimme look without ought else,
Remov'd all obstacles to Transmutation.
The Sheepherd is disguis'd without suspition,
And th' better to assist me to delude him;
The Metamorphosis was finisht, as
Montenor with my Sister did arrive,
Who instantly perceiving my designe,
So well reserv'd their countenance, they treat
Him for a Maid without the last suspition:
And thus out enterprise succeeded rarely.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Faith you provide us very excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Hircon.
sp.l: Il't ravish not, at least, 'twill make ye laugh;
But now to personate the Sheepherdesse,
Faire Nymph, you know what tis we have to doe.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Yes, I know well of what me must accuse him:

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Sure hee'l be very desparate in's defence,
When I to aid him shall employ my engine,
The Hall is most convenient for the purpose;
ãâã troubles, represented here,
ãââã pretty lights to my invention.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: I thought I'd lost ye, and was much perplext.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: We took the Aire upon the Fountain's side,
While you and Hircan have resolved how
Extravagant Lysis must be entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: And did the breath of Zephyrus delight ye?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My Sheepherdess did make it pleasant to me.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Your cares are constant.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: D'ye wonder at it?
Did ever any see me, and forsake me?

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Clarimond gives good evidence of that.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: To whom more justly could he render homage?
I dare engage with less baits heretofore,
Fauns were from Woods by Sheepherdesses drawn.
I have a quick, sweet lookâ

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: And a vain humour.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Not without reason, I come from the Fountaine,
Whose moving Christall since I have consulted,
A little vanity may be allow'd me.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Sure it flatter'd

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Not so much as you think,
But guesse whom I am like in our Romances:
What's rare, there by a Past'rall pencill drawn,
Is all but Copy I'm th' Originall,
In this disguise I'm nothing but is lovely,
I surpasse Philis, if not equall Astrea.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: You highly prize your selfe in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Charita is too faire to speak otherwise,
The best of Beauties may commend it selfe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: So wise a Druyde; Who would not believe?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I credit but my heart in this great Truth,
But as y'ave no defects, so be not cruell:
And to my perfect love vouchsafe to grant
A favour to adorne my Crookâthis shall
Sufficeâ

div.stage: (He snatches at a Ribbon, and Charita stops his hand.)

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: What doth this Sheepherd from Arcadia?
Expresly come to honour you in Brie,
And you refuse him that? Y'are strangely cruell.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Can he complain? I give when he demands.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Willingly?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yes, frankly Philiris, without disguise,
Provided Clarimond have no share in it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Why that Reserve so contrary to my vowes?
Explaine your selfe for Love-sake.â

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: It needs not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But in fineâ

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: No more, here's Montenor.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Well gentle Sheepherd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sister do you think

sp.speaker: Lysis
sp.l: the Sheepherdesse is come to see you?

sp.speaker: Lucida
sp.l: brings herâand you faire Charitaâ
I pray prepare your selfe to entertain her.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Be confident I will doe what I can;
He is confirm'd then of his Transformation.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He relies wholly upon Hircan's skill

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: We then shall see th' effects: Where left ye him?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Some thirty paces hence I came before.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Ile go then and prepare what's to be done.
It's very necessary I withdraw,
Lest if he finde me here, he should suspect
My art, that hitherto has hit so well.
I must appeare like a Magician here.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: That you may then avoid him, go this way,
I heare Lucida's tongue, th' are in the court.
What do you ow to this excess of Love?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: In Pastorals I shall be very famous.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Anselm knowes nothing of this Raillery.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: He'll be surpriz'd then with the more delight.
Let's here our Sheepherdess's complement.
See, there she is.â

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter to them Lucid. and Lysis like a Sheepherdesse.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: A very comely person!

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Fie laugh no more, in faith you'l spoile the Scene:
All contain your selves.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Fair Nymph to whom the Gods
The most mysterious Secrets doe impart;
In this unhappy Maid you see the Signes
Of griefs, which they have destin'd you to heale.
Thus saith great Hircan; and I took the care,
(Following his order) to conduct her hither.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: She is most welcom from so great a Druyde.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: You much oblige a distress'd Sheepherdess,
sp.stage: (imitating the voice and gesture of a maid.)
sp.l: Who will conclude her cruel fate most mild,
If she may have that blessing to be with you;
And that is all she begs.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Grant her desire;
To live among us Nymph she is prepar'd,
If you love our content refuse her not,
Most taking person!

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: She has excellent features

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What you say nothing?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I know what I think:
My debt to you impos'd this silence on me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: No, Philiris may e'en do what he please,
And yet he must be just to this rare beauty,
That excellently faire, deserves his homage,
See what quick beams are scatter'd from her face,
What eyes more faire ere captivated hearts?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Faire Sheepherdesse, pray spare my modesty,
Youle else soone raise Vermilion on my cheeks.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: So faire and perfect, all must needs commend you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Far short of meriting such Eulogies.
I'm but a Star compar'd to that bright Sun.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Perhaps you would boast more of your perfections,
Did you spend fewer teares in their possession.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: And what sad object can provoke her teares?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: To understand it Nymph, hear my misfortunes.
If the injurious Starre that rul'd my birth,
Had alwaies had for me kind influence,
I had appear'd here in as high condition,
As splendour of illustrions bloud allowes.
For I was born a Dam'sel (thanks to Heaven)
As you now see me reasonably faire,
And such, that truly from my youngest yeares,
I won the hearts of many thousand servants.
(Sad memory, which onely serves t'afflict me!)
I was styl'd every where faire Celimena,
And by that famous name did sweetly ravish,
Eclipsing many beauties that then shin'd;
But cruel Atropos killing my Father, I
Was soon constrain'd to be a Sheepherdesse:
I needs must yeild to force, and then assum'd
To please my Tyrants, the name of Amarillis,
Poore Amarillis, whom miseries in Troups,
Pardon my sighs that intercept my voice.
I can no farther go.â

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: A pretty story.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: She and my Brother have agreed to this.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Butâthis my forme, to me alone unhappy,
Unchang'd beheld the sad change of my fortune,
So far from leaving me in this new habit,
That tis fame filled all our villages,
All prais'd to envy, the new Sheepherdess:
Ev'ry one strove to see me, and to please me.
Happy till nowâbut onâthis high report
I wited three foule Satyrs from the Woods,
The infamies of whose lascivious loves
Were eccho'd every day through all our streames,
And these, to violate my chastity,
Dogg'd me in every place to ravish me;
And as last night I to the Fountain went,
Without the Sheepherd Filene, in their snares
They caught meâThis hath cast me at your feet,
These foule Goat-footed Fiends, the Nymphs obey:
Purge then from that base race ore sacred Groves;
Their whole employment is dishonourable.
All that they do's injurious and immodest.
Preserve the same of my Virginity:
Once, twice, and thrice on this I do depend:
Purge me from Satyrs, and I shall be spotless.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Your fate is cruellâbut yet cease to grieve,
You here have met with a safe Sanctuary:
The highest insolence, within this palace
Dares not attempt your Chastitie; live here,
From trouble free, Charita shall take care
Of those diversions are needfull for you,
Will you accept of her good companie?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Her affability speaks so high for her,
That instead of refusing I will strive
To follow her, as shadowes do their bodies,
And night and day, if I'm so blest, to please her.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: D'ye doubt it, faire and vertuous Sheepherdess?
How all my senses are transported! thus
To be possest of Amaryllis heart!
This glorious Modell of supremest Beauty!
This Starre!â

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Reserve these titles for your self;
If any thing in me seems radiant here,
'Tis by reflection of your eyes, faire Sun!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If you talk more, by these your kindnesses,
You'l robb me of my Mistris heart, I feare:
Come 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Indeed you may be jealous,
Having gain'd Amaryllis I scorn you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: By this you may oblige me to change too.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: T' enjoy an Angel, I shall lose a Mortall.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Is then my service of so little value?

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Let us end this discourse. Here's Polidore.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.l: We complain'd Sheepherd of your too long absence.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: In that I'm honour'd, and if I dispenseâ
But O ye Gods!

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: What Sheepherd, y'are surpris'd?
What is't that troubles you so suddenly?

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: A sudden brightnesse having struck my sight,
My senses all are charm'd, my soul disturb'd!
What Sheepherdess is that?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Do ye not know
The late felicities prepar'd for us?
And that fair Amaryllis hath made choice
Of these our coasts, t'embrace the care of flocks?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Most glorious coasts! oh spend here all your daies;
The Spring to please you here shall ever reigne,
Many new Flowers in the plaines shall rise.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Excuse me, for I talk to my Companion;
Having heard nothing, I shall answer nothing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: In fine, pray let's know wherefore we lost you,
What business made you dis-appear so long?

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: I was extreamly troubled for poore Lysis,
Lest after your Decree fatall despaire
Might make his Rival happy in his death;
So to prevent his violence on himself,
I ran thorough all the Woods with extream care,
But can learn nothing of him, and I feare
The streams of Marne have finished his fate.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: So after lesse injustice Celadon
Sought in the flouds of Lignon a Precipice;
Doubtlesse hee's deadâoh this guilty beauty!

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: But y'are too quick thus to conclude him dead.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: A secret horrour which doth seize my minde
Of this sad accident's a sure presage
To me, that he is drown'dâoh envious fates!

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: The goodnesse of the Gods could not permit it.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: He'l be their care, believe it Sheepherdesse;
He hath found necessary aid, Ile warrant,
Some Nymph or other will restore him to you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Alas, my dear Companion, I've lost all,
He doubtlesse did deserve a better end,
For of all Sheepherds he was the most faithfull.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: His name was brought even to our Villages,
Where all extoll'd him for's fidelity.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Deare Amaryllis, had you knowne him, he
Was the most perfect Sheepherd Heav'n ere saw,
His extream mildness, grace, and his demeanour,
Would have constrain'd you to have wish'd him well,
He gain'd all hearts!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: For Love sake be contented.
You lose a Lover, and I fill his place,
The homage which I pay to your divine.â

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Away vile Sheepherd speak no more to me;
Thy journy from Arcadia caus'd my grief,
Destroy'd my quiet and my Sheepherds life,
Into these flouds that drown my happiness:
Thou, and thy love did me precipitate.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Mod'rate thy passion.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Dost thou desire it? Then
Remove thy presence from my just displeasure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ever so full of rigour?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis resolved.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Thus to endure unjust disdaines too much.
Ingratefull Sheepherdesse, respect till now,
Made me suppresse my flame, now 't must break forth,
And I affirm, to brave your fury, that
My heart and eyes are sensible as yours.
Faire Amaryllis, the mildnesse of your charmes,
Force me with pleasure thus to yeild my self,
I break your former chaines t'obey your lawes:
What, you look down? Give me at least an answer;
Allow some hope unto my am'rous soule.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Maids are asham'd to hear discourse of love,
Approve my silence, or else change your Theme.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh wonder! Beauty fatal to my rest,
How from those Rosie lips one kiss obtain'd,
Would ease the Wounds which that faire eye hath given me!

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Keep your designes in bounds of honesty:
You injure much my modesty, I ought
To keep my self as chast as is Diana.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: One kisse is lawful; What power interdicts it?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: I and Charita mutually may kiss,
Without the censure of incontinence,
This sign of love to us is lawful, but
To kiss a Sheepherd who doth authorize it?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Yet having none but chast designs for you,
I sure may swear it upon these fair hands.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Away Prophane, thy fault's without compare,
You may as well a Vestal touch as me.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: You lose respect Sir.â

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I confesse I do.
But who knows what he does, that dies for love?

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: You oughtâbut Gods! how is my soul confounded?
Mine eyes deluded, or I see a Satyr.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter (to them) three of Montenors Servants, disguised like Satyrs.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Be not amaz'd, fair Nymphs, that we do now,
To haunt your Palaces, forsake our Woods,
Friends of Tautates, and Demi-Gods of Nature.
We soon perceiv'd that we were injured,
And hither we are come with just displeasure,
To demand justice for your selves and us.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: 'Gainst whosoere it be you shall receive it:

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: From Amaryllis snares we would secure you.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: My snares? what's that you filthy ugly Leacher?

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Pray, without injury, let's hear him out.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: The false report of that perfidious soul
Made you believe that she is chast, as faireâª
And that that glorious Lamp, which gives us light,
If he shine brighter, yet he is lesse pure;
But we must tell you, her incontinence,
With great God Pan, till now hath past in silence,
And our respect made us endure it, as loath
To speak of it, at all, to her dishonour;
But since with too much vice displeasing him,
She with the God Sylvanus was surpris'd,
And with a Faun too in Adultery,
Sh' hath arm'd your indignation against us,
Deceiving you by a base Artifice:
We therefore hither came to beg your justice.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Then answer Sheepherdesse.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: My heart ev'n bleeds:
How have I sinned? What fault have I committed?
This plot is laid by envy 'gainst my vertue:
Thus Phoedra ruin'd chast Hyppolytus.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Guilty or not, since they accuse you, we
Must purge you from suspition for our honour.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Oh Christian Chastity, clear Innocence!
With this attempt, alas, they vow my ruine.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Such crimes as this were never disavow'd,
But instantly they offer'd proofs by fire.
You Nymph do understand our Country's lawes,
And to what end the sacred Plate's ordain'd:
Then let her touch it burning, we shall see
If that chast and pure fire will spare her body.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What saist Barbarian?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Deare soul of my soule!
Expose thee Amaryllis to the fire?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Leave me to dissipate their wild suspitions;
Thus chast, I safe can walk on burningâª coales.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: This ancient custome, although rigorous,
Was never yet injurious to th' opprest;
If wrongfully accus'd, the fire will clear you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Why should I reverence this unjust law?
No, Amaryllis falsly thus accused,
Shall ne're be subject to it, Ile first die:
Let's see who dares accuse her?

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: How bold Sheepherd!
Will you provoke the anger of the Gods?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In this condition I fear not their anger:
My Gods, are my fair Sheepherdesse, and Love,
And rather than lose her, they may oblige me.â

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take hence this insolent Sheepherd from my sight;
Satyrs away with him.

div.stage: (While the Satyrs remove Clarim. Thunder and Lightning is heard.)

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Heavens! Earth revenge!
Th' oppresse him that defendeth innocence.
Unhappy maid! they envy that thou livest.
Aid me, sage Hircan, wisest Hircan aid!

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Strange Lightning!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Where shall be my Sanctuary?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: I cannot stir I am so full of feare.

div.stage: (All flie, and Hircan appeares in the air in a flying Chaire.)

div.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Thus by me Horror through these places flies,
And I those dangers break to which fates throw
Thee Amaryllis, raise thine eyes,
And th' Author of thy Transmutation know;
Since every day they threaten thee,
I in my flying chair come to thine aid;
Behold! how thy Foes insolence is staid,
And see how my approach they flee,
And how the feares of death do make
Their vanquisht fury all its force forsake!

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Vouchsafe, illustrious and learned Judge,
To free me from a trial forc'd upon me.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: I know't but little could their force prevail,
For thou art chast, and hast orecome the fire.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Yes, I as Amaryllis, had prevail'd;
But having once consulted with my soul,
I fear'd your charms enfeebled by the fire,
I should be Lysis more than Amaryllis.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Fear not; I come through midst of clouds, and crost
An hundred unknown paths in this my chair.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Is the way safe?

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Yesâbut it will be best
That for prevention you blind your eyes.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: I willingly obey the wisest Druyde,
Whose will commands ore the decrees of Fate.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: 'Tis time to part, up and take courage, know
No dangers dare affront thee where I go:

div.trailer: The end of the third Act.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: HIs eyes betray the secrets of his soule,
Th' have more than once inform'd me of his flame,
And I've too well observ'd Lucida's lsforgetove
Alone engag'd him to become a Sheepherd,
So that from the first moment that I knew it,
I fed his fires in suff'ring them to rise;
And I can now no more, without injustice,
Forget a secret promised consent,
Montenor's worthy, but, for all his merit,
Th' intrest of my Sister more weighs with me;
I am her Brother, and she must remember,
That though she give her self, he cannot have her.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Think not that his extream affection
Would imploy any but himselfe to gain her;
And in that conquest he presum'd his strong
Endeavours should prevaile 'bove humane Empire:
But do he what he can, a brother's needfull
To force that duty so resolv'd in silence,
And which, though you consent not, will not suffer
A sigh escape, that may detect his secret.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: If this sole obstacle thwart his desires,
He ought to praise th' effect of a fair cause:
But Ile take order strait to stop its progress.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: For mine own int'rest, I presume to press you,
For (if I must explain my selfe) I saw
Less in my self, than in fair Angelica;
I adore her, and her brother aids my vowes,
But yet to crown them he must first be happy:
That's passion finding kind effects, may let himâª
See, without Envy, my Felicity.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Heel see it doubtless, and's contented mind
Shall have that fair success your love attends:
But now 'tis time our Past'rall Sports give way
To pleasures of a nobler quality.
Lysis too much is fool'd, and w'ave too long
Cherisht an Errour which ere this had ended.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Your Art's incapable of such a cure.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Yet 'tis by that I make him tractable:
In our last Scene he so rely'd upon me,
That in a flying Chair I sent him home.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Yet more of Amaryllis?

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Somewhat of Mysterie
Made up the charm and spoil'd the Sheepherdess:
Then with a secret Spell's unerring power,
I was to force the Nymph to entertain him.
You know the entertainment, what address
He made to's Mistriss in that interview,
Which mov'd her on the fiction of his death
To speak, and countenance his airy Fables.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: He's very full of them.

sp.speaker: Hircan.
sp.l: Th' are all his study:â
But as I long to be alone again,
Charita, who I see's arriv'd i'th' Park,
Is a faire obstacle to one would muse,
I therefore must avoid herâfare ye well.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: 'Tis a dark solitory humour, this.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: What, without Lysis beauteous Sheepherdess?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The Nymph i'th' Hall at leisure entertains him,
Where Maugre all his love respect retaines him:
But why doth Hircan shun us with such cares?

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Faith he's injurious to Charita's beauty.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: But Ile be satisfied since't has no witness.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: 'Tis solitude that busies all his care,
And any pastime that's without himself,
Is a great torment to his musing minde.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: You will not find it in that kind consent,
Which he gives freely to an happy Lover.
Montenor.â

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Sister pray admire with me,
That Plain, which gives us here so sweet a prospect.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: ButâSister there is mystery in this language.
Does your mind wander with your eyes or no?
What, you blush?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Pish away.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Well, I pardon
The so secret disorder of your heart:
I fine.â

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: You credit then this Barber's talk?

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: No, no, give no belief to what I say.
Farewell, Ile seek one that in this affaire,
Shall have more Rhetorick to perswade you: I
At least am sure, upon such pleasing terms,
Montenor rather will hear me than you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: But Sister, is he gone without more words?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: I endure all from you who onely seek
To laugh.â

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Indeedâbut let us speak in earnest;
Let's call him back again t' explain himself.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Wherefore should I desire his explanation?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Oh the sad Vertue that now stings thy mind!
Doth Montenor, in all his service to you,
Shew mean effects of an indifferent zeal?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: If I believe his sighs, I reign in's soul.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Doubtless you are ingrateful to his flame.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: And wherefore should his hopes by me be flatter'd?
Can he be ignorant of what's my desires?
If he hath gain'd my Brother, what needs more?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Indeed this modest answer fits our times;
It's worthy you, and I my selfe esteem it:
But 'mong our selves let's lay by all disguise;
Confess with me our mindes are easily
Led thither, whither we desire to go,
And that they need not struggle for obedience,
When as our Duty, and our Love agree.
But when that Love, which does command in chief,
Finds in that Duty that which would depress it,
It quickly cures us of that ancient errour,
Which would debarre us to dispose our hearts.
No, no, if Montenor could not have pleas'd you,
Ye would not in that choice believe a brother:
Your flames would finde a very weak support,
If they were fed but by another's order

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: You do assault me with such cunning, that
At length you force me to confess my weakness.
I love him, and my heart before possest,
With love's perplext.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Is the great secret out?
And why should love in this our age, in us
Be weakness, and a vertue in the men?
Why should we blush at our so faultless flames?
Do we want eyes to see, or hearts to love?
I know that ancient modesty requir'd,
We should seem shie even at the name of Love.
And if a servant do pretend to court us,
We must cry out before we hear him speak:
But though w'impose a silence on these sweets,
We nothing lesse seek than obedience;
And any servant would court us but ill,
Who to talk Gazets should suppress his love.
Those kinde refusalls to hear no such language,
Are but faire invitations to say more.
In fine, we all desire that they should love us,
And often run by secret plots to meet them.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Gods! you know all.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: More, happily, than you,
But your desires contented make less shew:
Yet since that love is ready now to fix you,
Ile gather flowers to compose your Garland.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: If Love oblige you to compose a Garland,
He'l give it by your hands to Clarimond,
And see how full of joy he comes to take it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And yet in love Lucida must know nothing.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: No, I know nothing but the common rule,
That to two Lovers any third's a trouble.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Clarimond. (Smiling as he approaches Charita.)
div.l: 'Tis sheâI see her gath'ring heaps of Flowers
In this ennamell'd Park, of divers colours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Th'approach is Past'rall, but my new Filene
I've right to answer as your cruell Sylvia.
Take heed.â

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How carelesly you heare these lines,
Without a thought of him that lent 'em me:
He was unhappy, but I hope I shall
Once touch the heart of my fair Sheepherdesse.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis not of stone, and your continuall cares
Deserve esteem, perhaps a little more:
But whither can the flames that rule us go?
Somtimes we wish a Lover would daign it,
That he may force our hearts, and that his fires
Surprized by a look may read the secrets.â

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Too happy Clarimond! what canst pretend?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Let not our want of understanding make us
Mistake, and, if your freedome answers mine,
Let's divide Philiris from Clarimond.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But what proceedings yours can equalize,
To make one happy, and reject the other?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You easily may guess the reason; one's
A Courtier, t'other is a simple Sheepherd.
For me, if I may their defence assume,
I ever lov'd the freedome of the Sheepherds;
Those cheating outsides of your begging sighs,
Those so well studyed, languishing aspects,
Those affectations of a wandring minde,
Are not the colours which their love appeares in:
They expresse themselves in a serener aire,
And when they vow they love, they love indeed,
And in the sweet transports of guiltlesse flames,
They promise nothing which the heart denies.
And so when kindly Philiris assur'd me,
That ore his captivâªd heart I reign'd alone,
Not fearing to be sacrific'd to fraud,
I told him that I something did believe,
But farre from a resolve to flatter him
In his desiresâIf Clarimond spake thus
With more reserve, and more retention.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh pray, pursue not a discourse that kils me;
And, since his freedom answers for his faith,
Let Philiris now speak for Clarimond,
For he will keep his passion very secret,
If Philiris dares not to interpret it,
Under that borrowed name which he assumes,
He opens you his soule, and speaks his heart,
And his pure flame, aspiring to extreams,
When he does say he loves, he loves you truly.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: This satisfies not what I ow my self,
To dare to credit Clarimond on his Faith,
No, no, 'tis for his honour, he sweares to me,
That nothing's comparable to what he suffers,
But all that I can do, mine not engag'd,
Is to endure complaint, and not believe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Are you then doubtfull of so true a flame?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: To wish it so, I am too just, for know
I Clarimond do understand, at Court
'Tis Vertue quaintly to dissemble Love
That it is gallant to declare to all,
You are a friend to th' Brown as well as Faire,
And without giving bounds to your desires,
Your sighs can menage as you see occasion.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh cease to injure the sincerest flame,
That purest love ere kindled in a soule;
Do I insensible of constant love
On all occasions, divide my heart?
And sigh in every place at any object?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I know that nothingâªs easier than to say so,
And flatter thus our foolish vanity,
That breeds in us too much credulity.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Thus to persist so long in vain alarms,
Is to distrust the power of your Beauty,
'Tis true, to please an hundred sev'rall objects,
Men may dissemble wounds they never had,
That it is easie still to say I love you.
But you may know 'tis not the same with you,
And 'tis impossible to see your face,
And say I love you, and not love you truly.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And would you have me to believe you now?
But see our Foole.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Base hindrance to my Joy!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: To vex him for the mischief he hath done you,
I will abuse him with pretended sleep:
Farewell, leave me alone, I think 'tis best
That you and I be not surpriz'd together.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Butâ

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Leave me I say, or I shall break with you.

div.stage: (She lies down upon the grasse pretending to sleep)

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And must this foole disturb such pleasing minutes?
But to please my Charita, Ile avoid him,
And let her sport with his extravagance.

div.head: SCENE V.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Sweet places, where my Sun beneath your shade,
Having scorch'd me, repairs to take the aire,
Though to be lightned be your great advantage,
Yet suffer a poore Sheepherd to share with you.
Hide not Charita from th' most ardentâbut
Gods! I'm deluded, or I see her sleeping.
'Tis sheâoh happiness! hush gentle Zephyrs,
Breath without noise, my Goddess is asleepâ
I must advance, but slowly, lest I wake her.
Trees, let your leaves be silent for a while:
Ye Brooks stand still, and you, ye foolish Bees,
That buzze so busily about her eares,
Fly hence, touch not the Roses which I see;
My fairest hath no flowers but for me.
How happy's Morpheus? O transcendent beauty,
In the worlds fairest eyes to have his Palace!
How he tasts Nectar sweet and most delicious!
And how his happinesse thy Sheepherd envies!
Oh if't were lawfulâbut thou insolent Fly,
Which on that fairest Nose presum'st to sitâ
Ile make thee know what 'tisâ

div.stage: (beating away the Flie he strikes her on the face, which she pretends wakes her.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Gods how you use me!
Why did you not awake me gentlier?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Oh!â
Pardon an act of justice to my Flame,
Which thought it duty so to sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: What have you caus'd me suffer by that blow?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Love seldom gives a wound he cannot cure.
But though you feel some little pain by that,
Yet might that cursed Fly have stung youâfor
You know that once Eudoxa.â

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: She did well:
But if it were her fault, it is not mine.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: At least for pity-sake.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What Sheepherd?â

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Cruel.
Thou daily dost permit the Sun to kiss thee,
And will not suffer that this amorous heart,
Should by thy snow seek to refesh his heat.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The sad condition that your heart is in.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Thy hand of milk congeal'd may make the proof.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good Gods!

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Absolve a Lover from that error;
I know the love of Sheepherds should be chast,
But yet their soules sometimes may be transported,
And Nature of her self is vitious.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Oh how the impure flames I finde in you,
Constraine me to regrate my Amaryllis!

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Amaryllis?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Did you love her?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I love her
More, though she's absent, than I do my self,
That I might see her?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: That you may easily
Remove what hides her from thy abused eyes,
See here thy Sheepherd.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What is't you would say?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: That Amaryllis onely breaths in me,
And my excessive love that could not be
Prevented, made me change my sex to see thee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You would have chang'd to force the obstacles.
